The patient is a 50-year-old female with a history of COPD, diabetes mellitus type II, IgG/IgA deficiency, and MRSA epidural abscess. She underwent thoracic spinal fusion 35 days prior and has had multiple complications and infections requiring re-operation. She was transferred from the surgical intensive care unit (SICU) to the medical intensive care unit (MICU) for further management.

1. Hypercarbic Respiratory Failure - The patient has been difficult to liberate from the ventilator due to low tidal volumes, especially in the setting of narcotics. It is necessary to continue a slow ventilatory wean and consider a trial of extubation when sedation is minimized.

2. Persistent Fevers - Possible etiologies include unresolved ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP), fungal urinary tract infection (UTI), persistent abscess in the spine/paraspinal space, pleural effusions/atelectasis, and drugs. Further investigations such as magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the spine, empirical treatment of urine with fluconazole, minimizing unnecessary medications, and following blood culture data are recommended.

3. MRSA Epidural Abscess - The patient would benefit from further imaging of the spine given persistent drainage from the wound. IV vancomycin and rifampin for MRSA osteomyelitis should be continued until July 5th.
